sub_title: Scientific Software Engineer | Applied Physicist & Econometrist | Model Building, Algorithm Design and Code Development | REMOTE
summary:
Looking for someone who loves to tackle big challenges? I am eager to apply both my strong analytical and soft skills to think outside the box and come up with effective solutions to challenging problems. With a strong growth mindset, I aim to contribute to a company’s common goals and participate in meaningful work for society.  

Ideally, I am looking to apply my skills in an international environment focused on: analytical problem solving, mathematical model building, simulations and software engineering, while utilising soft skills as well. 

I am ready to focus on a new challenge, following up on the goals I have already achieved in my life.  For example, as a teenager I devoted my time to pole vaulting, where I continuously challenged myself to jump higher. By training full-time and competing on an international level I managed to jump, among others, to nine Dutch titles and two Dutch all-time records. Subsequently I dived deep into university life, where I constantly searched for extracurricular challenges to develop myself in various areas while strengthening a broad range of skills. I managed to excel by completing one Bachelor and two Masters Cum Laude, three fruitful internships (at Harvard University, in Rio de Janeiro and at an analytical consulting company), a successful board year, an elected position in the university council and many more interesting projects. Thereafter I challenged myself to follow my sense of adventure and curiosity and live in a Volkswagen Kombi on the road in South America, while learning valuable life lessons and focusing on personal growth. 

In conclusion, my characteristics include analytical thinking, perseverance, diversity, independence, pro-activity, commitment, adaptability, honesty and I love to contribute to a healthy and pleasant work environment. I have experience with Python, C++, shell scripting, Matlab, Mathematica, R, AIMMS, HTML, CSS and I am not afraid to work with new languages. Furthermore, I am flexible location-wise and also available for remote work.

publications.name: Coordinated collective migration and asymmetric cell division in confluent human keratinocytes without wounding

profile_positions.title: Mathware Engineer

profile_positions.description:
After buying a Volkswagen T2 in Brazil and rebuilding the interior to make it a small home, I lived on the road in several countries in South America. There I visited fascinating places, met countless wonderful people and experienced many special and unique situations, which were all rewards stemming from my independence and creativity along with taking initiative and being communicative.  

Several complex mechanical issues, political unrest in Chile and the Corona lock-down in Argentina has taught me to deal with serious setbacks and to find creative solutions in unknown situations. Nevertheless, persistence and commitment didn’t abate and made this extended and adventurous journey possible. 

While in South America, I improved my Portuguese and learned Spanish (both with disciplined self-study and practice with local people); challenged myself physically by e.g. climbing to 6000m+, surviving several days in the jungle with only a machete, learning to kite surf and hiking for 7+ days; joined two times the NomadCruise, a 2-week digital nomad conference at sea, where I learned valuable work and life lessons of which many I could readily apply; took the time to read and think about self-development; and I made sure I satisfied my analytical mind by learning new programming languages and implementing e.g. a complex finance tracker.
profile_positions.title: Overlander, Explorer and Adventurer with a Volkswagen Kombi in South America

profile_positions.description:
In my graduation research (graded 9.5/10) in the group Theory of Polymers and Soft Matter, we applied a complex theory from condensed matter physics (mode-coupling theory) to describe the movement of epithelial cells in e.g. wound healing, cancer and asthma and we showed that these cells behave similarly to non-living materials below the glass transition. In addition, we developed a new model to describe collective cell migration to explain recent experimental observations, which is published in Nature Communications (see publication below). Part of my research I executed at the Harvard School of Public Health in the United States (see below).

The major part of my research consisted of mathematical modelling and simulation of epithelial cell layers, analytical derivation and adaptation of a complex theory (mode-coupling theory), and numerical application of this theory on the simulated as well as on experimental data. Furthermore, my project included extensive literature research and (re)defining research questions, interpreting results and creating follow up steps, communication of my ideas through many presentations and heavy discussions, and scientific writing for an article and a comprehensive report. 

For me it was important to have a thorough understanding of the subject, models and theories and to be proactive by e.g. taking the lead regarding the project development and in meetings. To delve deeper into the subject and to discuss my research, I visited at own initiative several prominent researchers (Harvard, Boston university, Columbia university) in both the fields of condensed matter and biophysics. Furthermore, I made sure I worked structured, determined and independent along with being disciplined and perseverant.  

Programming software and languages: C++, Matlab, Python, Shell Scripting
profile_positions.title: Graduate Research Intern - Applied Physics

company.name: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

profile_positions.company: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
profile_positions.description:
Part of my physics graduation project (graded 9.5/10) I executed at the Harvard School of Public Health in the group of molecular and integrative cellular dynamics. My research proposal and the subsequent execution resulted in a fruitful two-way exchange of knowledge: I was able to explain and lead discussions about a complex theory (mode-coupling theory) new in their field (biophysics), while the hosting group explained and provided me with experimental data to support the applicability of this theory.

During this exchange I gained valuable experience in presenting and explaining an abstract theory to a group of professors and other academics as well as answering complex questions about this topic. In addition, I learned to lead in-depth discussions varying from complex mathematical concepts and derivations to philosophical concepts about the theoretical validity and applicability. Furthermore, I got the opportunity to work with experimental data and learned how to use them in combination with simulations and theory. Taking initiative and being proactive were key factors during this internship as well as strong presentation and communication skills.  

Program software and languages: C++, Matlab, Python, Shell Scripting
profile_positions.title: Graduate Research Intern - Applied Physics

profile_positions.description:
As part of my Master's degree in Econometrics, I did an extended internship (graded 9.0/10) at CQM (Consultants in Quantitative Methods). For one of their clients, we implemented different matching methods combined with several auction pricing strategies in order to design an efficient freight matching platform. 

I used both exact methods (linear programming) and algorithms (simulated annealing, machine learning) to design and simulate different matching and pricing strategies, which I then compared using key performance indicators based on the requests of the client. In this project I also had the opportunity to gain experience in valuable consulting skills such as transforming the preferences and requests of a client into a project, asking a client for essential information and data, presenting the project development and (pre)results to a client, and adapting a project according to the client’s feedback. Furthermore, I did an extensive literature research (both regarding the specific industry and mathematical methods), combined available knowledge by gathering the right people, and presented my research to a broad audience both orally and written. 

For me it was important to rise above the subject, to take initiative and be proactive, and to take the lead regarding the project development and during meetings. I made sure I worked systematic, disciplined and independent along with being perseverant in obtaining valuable results and satisfying the client.  

Programming software and languages: AIMMS, Matlab, Python
profile_positions.title: Graduate Research Intern - Econometrics

company.name: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

profile_positions.location: Rio de Janeiro en omgeving, Brazilië
profile_positions.company: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
profile_positions.description:
As a part of my Master's program in Applied Physics, I did an internship abroad (graded 9.0/10) at the Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (Brazil). In the group of Condensed Matter Physics, we  investigated analytically and numerically the time-evolution of multiple systems consisting of two coupled quantum dots and came up with an elegant analytical derivation for a specific equation within this field (Landau-Zenner equation). 

Working and living in a foreign country with a different culture has broaden my view highly and taught me to adapt easily to a new environment and working methods. Furthermore, I gained experience with analytical research and numerical analyses as well as presenting and writing about scientific research. To enhance my communication in a non-English speaking country, I took a course in Portuguese and became able to conversate in daily life as well as at university. 

Programming software and languages: Mathematica, Matlab
profile_positions.title: Research Intern (Internship Abroad) - Applied Physics

company.name: Study association for applied physics "J.D. van der Waals"

profile_positions.company: Study Association for Applied Physics "J.D. van der Waals"
profile_positions.description:
During my entire study period I was an active member of our study association by taking part in numerous committees, two fraternities and one board year. This gave me the opportunity to organise many activities from educational activities to freshmen activities and from sports activities to study tours abroad. Furthermore, I volunteered for over three years as a bar tender for our weekly faculty drinks. 

I especially liked to set up new activities and create a solid base to assure their recurrence. For example, in my board year I was responsible for setting up a winter sports week for the first time; I was part of the organisation committee of the first camping week to visit several Belgian breweries; I set up a new fraternity with fifteen people; and I set up or joined the organisation of several special weekends and other activities that where held for the first time and has now become yearly activities. 

In these committees and fraternities, I got assigned to different functions like chairman, treasurer, secretary and advisory member. This gave me the possibility to develop myself in different roles within a group as well as in team collaboration. Furthermore I gained a lot of experience in being responsible, organising and being practical. Lastly, being part of these organisational teams was very satisfying and enabled further development of my soft skills.
profile_positions.title: Chairman, Treasurer, Secretary and Member of Numerous Committees

profile_positions.company: Study Association for Applied Physics "J.D. van der Waals"
profile_positions.description:
During a full-time board year of the study association (with over 600 members and more than 150 yearly activities), I fulfilled the role of Commissioner External Affairs and was responsible for the contact with about 100 companies via mail, phone and regular visits. Together with these companies, I created events and other opportunities for them to get in touch with potential employees as well as possibilities for students to meet potential employers and get informed about the job market. This resulted in a record amount of sponsoring income and a pleasant collaboration with many recruiters. In addition, I could develop my organisational and communication skills and gain experience in being proactive, constructive, flexible and practical. 

As part of the board I also performed many tasks to keep the association running and to organize activities, in which I built up experience in e.g. responsibility, leadership and time management. Working intensively together with six people has taught me to collaborate on a high level and gave me valuable insights about my role in a group. For example, group cohesion is important for me as well as having an overview of what is happening and I often come up with out-of-the-box ideas and suggestions. The powerful lessons I have learned during this board year still benefit me today.
profile_positions.title: Commissioner for External Relations - Board Year

profile_positions.description: Elected by the department’s (student) population, my main task as member of the Department Council was to monitor critically the general work of the department and make proposals to the departmental board. Major topics were the recent commissioning of the new departmental building and the implementation of the new master program that would start the following year.
profile_positions.title: Department Council (Student Member) - Applied Physics

profile_positions.description:
Elected by the university’s student population, I acquired a seat in the University Council as part of the largest student party (Groep-één). My election meant representing the students in university-wide topics during meetings of the University Council and smaller committee meetings (16 hours per week). Within the party I was responsible for the portfolio ‘Education’ and was therefor the chairman of both the Bachelor College committee and the Graduate School committee, which consisted of respectively the Deans of this Bachelor and Graduate education system and a delegation of the employee party and student parties. Main task of the Bachelor committee was the monitoring and evaluation of the recently implemented Bachelor College (a new education system that completely revised all the bachelors of the university) and to review the Program and Exam Regulation in order to be approved in the University Council. Within this committee, we achieved some significant successes of which the whole university population benefited. Meanwhile, the main task of the Graduate School committee was to review and approve for the first time the Program and Exam Regulation of the Graduate School (a new education in which all the masters are completely revised), which started the following year. My role as chairman was to collect and evaluate the comments of the Department Councils and discuss them with the Dean, which has led to several adaptions of the regulation.

I gained experience in formal and informal meetings on a high political level. For example, I learned to ask well-formulated questions to the leaders of the university and to defend the students’ interests and concerns. It was important for me to constantly be up-to-date, stay pro-active and address the topics clearly. I always made sure to work structured and to be well-prepared, which has lead to constructive meetings and positive relationships with the people involved.
profile_positions.title: University Council (Student Member) - Fraction Groep-één

profile_positions.description:
As student chairman of the Education Committee, I was responsible for the students’ input in meetings about departmental education-related topics with the Director of Education. Furthermore, I executed the role of chairman of the meetings in absence of the general chair.  With the four student members I held pre-meetings to discuss on-going topics within the department, created action plans and set up subcommittees if necessary. In my role I also divided the tasks between the other members and ensured that the topics were addressed in the meetings of the Education Committee. Main topics were the evaluation of the recently implemented bachelor program and the development of a new master program.

For me one of the main successes was the identification of a discrepancy in the curriculum, setting up an interdisciplinary committee of students and professors, and present possible solutions to the Departmental Board, which has eventually led to a shift in the curriculum to add a new mathematics course. As student chairman of the Education Committee I gained experience in chairing, meetings at a departmental level, being responsible and delegating tasks as well as recognising (educational) issues and creating action plans.
profile_positions.title: Education Committee (Student Chairman) - Applied Physics

profile_positions.description: As student representative of the Department of Applied Physics and together with representatives from all other departments, I joined regular meetings with the Dean of the Bachelor College to evaluate this new Bachelor education system (which was implement one year earlier).
profile_positions.title: Advisory Committee Bachelor College (Student Member)

profile_positions.description: As member of the outreach team of Applied Physics, I informed prospective students about the study at open days, school visits and experience days. One of my task was to give presentations about the study in lecture halls full of people and in front of class rooms. To be able to do so I joined multiple presentation training sessions and learned how to make a presentation interactive and interesting. During in-house days, I managed the extra students who were helping and I was in charge of the booth of Applied Physics. At this booth, we took our time to answer the questions of prospective students and their parents. In these conversations, enthusiasm and honesty were very important to me.
profile_positions.title: Outreach Team - Applied Physics

profile_positions.description:
As part of my Bachelor's program in Applied Physics, I did a theoretical internship (graded 9.0/10) in the group of Theory of Polymers and Soft Matter. In this research we derived analytical formulas for the deformation of liquid crystal droplets exposed to external fields and verified the results using experimental data. Besides gaining experience in analytical research, I also learned to discuss scientific research and present my results both orally and written.  

Program software and languages: Mathematica
profile_positions.title: Undergraduate Research Intern - Applied Physics

profile_positions.description: As a student member of the Education Committee of Applied Physics, I represented the students regarding educational topics in meetings with the departmental Director of Education. After one year, I was appointed student chairman (see above).
profile_positions.title: Education Committee (Student Member) - Applied Physics

profile_positions.description:
Starting with pole vault from a young age, I grew better and I practised on a more serious level every year. At the age of fifteen I started to train with the national coach in a group with international athletes, which soon involved moving two hours from my home city and joining a full-time training program. This has led to nine Dutch youth titles, two Dutch youth all-time bests and competing on an international level in addition to having a lot of fun while jumping and challenging myself physically every day. 

While I might not have been as talented as others physically, I compensated this with training hard and disciplined. Attitude and perseverance determined my pole vault results, while I learned many mental skills and valuable psychological lessons by training daily and competing on a high level. For example, I learned how to develop a mindset for success, to set (realistic) goals and to work towards them effectively. I gained experience in dealing with successes and high expectations as well as dealing with disappointing results and subsequently turning the page. In total, these experiences have determined my character and today I still benefit from these mental skills and lessons.
profile_positions.title: Pole Vault Athlete
